text:
- In this technical episode
of AWS Cloud Adventures,
we will talk about how Wallester
built their card issuing platform.

I'm Muhammad Sajid, Senior
Solutions Architect at AWS,

and with me I have
Andrei, CTO of Wallester.
Welcome Andrei.

- Thank you, Muhammad.
It's a pleasure to be here.

- You have developed this
card issuing platform.
I want you to go through the architecture
and how you built it.
- Yeah, sure.
So the development of our platform
started at the beginning of 2017.
And from the really beginning,

we wanted to have our
platform developed internally

because we wanted to
keep all the knowledge
about our platform inside of the company.

And we also wanted to have
our platform really scalable

and use this as a competitive
advantage for our platform.

Looking at our partners
or potential partners,
so most of them had solutions on premise,

but we thought that it's
not beneficial for us
because as a small company, as a startup,

we didn't have much
resources and time actually
and the money to spend on all of that,
on building all of that.

So we thought that probably
we should start in the cloud.

And hopefully we had a good
DevOps engineer in our team
with advanced knowledge in AWS.
So we started to use your platform, AWS,

and started to build
something in the cloud.

- I hope that was not the
only reason to choose AWS
for deploying your solution.
- Yeah, sure, because we used AWS

not only because of
our engineer obviously,

so because of the cutting edge
solutions AWS cloud provides
and the security and scalability.

So because of all of that, we
started to use the platform.
To enable Cartesian's platform,
we integrated with a lot of partners

including personalization
centers, card processes,

3D secure providers, card
schema, in our case it's Visa,

to payment gateways to SMS
gateways, to banks and others.
And for our white label clients,

we actually provide just one
integration endpoint with us.

This is goes through
our simple, a REST API,

just one integration
point for our clients.
So we're helping them to streamline
the card issuing platforms programs,

which they can build on
on top of our platform.
So talking about architecture,
we use multi-service architecture.
We built and deploy our code
using CodeBuild and CodePipeline.
The core of our infrastructure is EKS
where all our services are running.

- Right, so when you have a
multi-service architecture
or a microservices architecture,

multiple services often need
to communicate with each other.
So how do you develop this?

How does your services
communicate with each other?
- Yeah, true.
So we basically have two options,
how our services are communicated.

First is a synchronous way
and for that we use GLPC.

And for asynchronous way,
we use SNS and SQS together.

Also for data storage, we
use Aurora with Postgres

and ElastiCache with Redis
for in memory storage.
We also utilize S3 for data storage
and we use KMS for our keys, certificates,
and all the sensitive information storage.
- You mentioned EKS.

Kubernetes is great, but
what benefits did you get
from the managed Kubernetes service?
- We primarily use EKS

because of its high
availability and scalability.
We also like that it's a managed service

because we don't need
to spend a lot of time

on configuration and maintenance
of Kubernetes in AWS.

Because of the dynamic
nature of our traffic,
especially in peak holiday seasons,

so EKS has helps us a lot
with the scaling up and down
based on the demand of the traffic coming.

Also in our infrastructure,
we have basically two parts
'cause we wanted to segregate
our non-PCI data from PCI data.

And in PCI zone, we use
more serverless solutions
like EKS with Fargate,

which helps us to achieve
PCI DSS certification.

- I can see security is
really important for you
and I want to know how did you achieve
your security requirements in AWS?
- Yes, you are right.

Managing regulatory compliance
for financial institutions
is very complex and time consuming task.

To obtain PCI DSS certifications,
actually not so easy.
It contains of 12 major requirements

that the system should satisfy
to achieve the certification.
And when the need arose for our platform
to be PCI DSS certified,

so we started to think how
to build the PCI zone there.

Most of our partners use on
premise solutions for that,

but we as a startup don't
have so many resources

to spend on building huge
solutions on premise.

We don't have so many
resources, time for that,

so we started to look how
we can do it much easier.
And as we already used AWS cloud,

we started to look what kind
of services AWS can offer to us
and we found that there are a lot

of PCI DSS compliance services
already provided by AWS
with a shared responsibility model.

So we started to build our
PCI zone in AWS cloud as well.

And I think it was really
straightforward for us
and we spend much less resources on that
compared to our partners.
One of the problems we needed to solve
is how to secure card data in our platform

because the requirement
is usually to have a HSM,
which is on premise,

and it's hard to achieve
that in the cloud.

But fortunately AWS provides
KMS key management service,

which is underneath using HSM
machines in Amazon clouds.

So we started to use KMS
and it actually helped us
to achieve the main security requirement

from PCI DSS to secure
card data in our databases.

So to sum up the PCI
DSS compliance services,
which AWS provided helped us

to be one of the first
card issuer in the cloud
who received a PCI DSS certification

and then enabled card
payment in the cloud.
- Fantastic.
I remember you talked

about infrastructure as
code in the beginning

and you also mentioned
couple of AWS services.
Can you go through a little bit more
how did you do the implementation?
- As I talked before,

for us it was very
important to quickly start

and to not spend much
resources on the infrastructure
and more focused on the development.

So we decided that we built
our infrastructure as a code.
So because there are multiple benefits
of using infrastructure as a code,

because it can help to
automate provisioning
of our resources in the infrastructure,
it also enables consistency
across all our regions and deployments.

Also, it provides versioning
for our infrastructure

and the tracking code for the
changes we might have there.

And it also helps to reduce
duplication of efforts
to implementing the same components
in different parts of the platform.
And it also helps to easily
and quickly implement new functionalities

to add new functionalities
to our platform.
Also, one of the benefit,
and I think it's very important one,

that we can easily
redeploy our infrastructure

in another region in case of
disaster recovery solutions
to keep our business continuity.
- Right.
It's always a good idea to avoid ClickOps

when we talk about
deployment in production.
Since you mentioned multi-region,

I would like to know what
are your plans in the future,
your scalability plans?

And you spoke about
multi-region deployment
in terms of failover, but what about,

do you have customers in other
regions and what's your plan?

- So let's start first
about the scalability
because as I said, we have chosen AWS
not only because of our engineer,

but also because of the
scalability and high availability.
So currently we use EKS

and it's very helpful for
the scalability issues,
so to match the demand with our resources.
The same for the database part,
we use Aurora Serverless version two,

which also helps us to scale
our database capabilities
based on the demand.

Then as you asked about
the different regions,
so currently we use just one region,
we deploy everything into Europe,
but in multiple availability zones.

As I mentioned, we tested
our disaster recoveries
where we deployed our infrastructure
in other region as well.

But currently most of our
clients are in Europe,

so we have all our
infrastructure in Europe region.

Our plans is of course to
have US and other regions
and the cloud provider risk capabilities

of having our infrastructure
in different regions
is actually very helpful here for us.
- Now I wanna know a little bit more

about your future plans,
your innovation plans,
and how AWS can help you.

- Sure, so I see basically
three main directions

how we're going to innovate
in the near future.

First, we have a lot
of data in our platform
and we want to use it more efficiently

to build reports based on
that to make some analysis.

And for that, we want to
build a data warehouse,

and I think that Amazon Redshift
will suit here very well.

Secondly, we want to
use more AI technologies
because we wanted to provide

more cutting edge
solutions to our clients,

and we will start with the
fraud monitoring system.

We can enhance it using, for
example, Amazon fraud detection
or SageMaker for the bespoke models there.

We also can prove our
internal productivity

by generative AI solutions
like Amazon Q, for example.

We can use it for our
development processes

and for building business
analytics using Amazon QuickSight.

The third thing, what I'm
currently thinking of,
is integration with Visa,
because, as you know, Visa is our partner

and we want to have a direct
connection with VisaNet.

There is a solution
called Visa Cloud Connect,

where we can connect our
virtual private cloud
with Visa private cloud,

and to have a direct connection
using Amazon Private Link.

And on top of that, we
are going to use CloudHSM

to secure all data transactions
through our platform.

- I really enjoyed our
conversation, Andrei,
and thank you very much for joining today.
- Yeah, thank you, Muhammad.

It was pleasure to talk
to you today as well.

- If you want to learn more
about the Wallester story
from a business perspective,

don't forget to check
out the business episode.
Thank you very much.
